summary: Valentine’s website for Jishone to ask Annammooo to be his valentine, featuring an interactive Yes/No prompt that escalates until Yes is chosen, then shows a popup with a custom image and romantic message; also support adding a custom image on the second response page via client-side image selection.
architectural_notes: Single-page Valentine website with interactive button logic and modal popup on success.
Homepage should include a static personal image (e.g., couple photo) referenced from frontend assets (no backend image serving).
Add a client-side image picker (file input) to let the user select a local image and render it on the homepage without requiring backend upload/serving.
Ensure displayed name text uses exact capitalization: “Annammooo” (not “annammooo”).
Add a client-side image picker (file input) on the second response page to render a user-selected image without backend upload/serving.

existing_features.title: Create a single-page Valentine’s website homepage that displays the question text: “annammooo will you be my valentine” with two buttons: “Yes” and “No”.

Implement the interactive escalation behavior for the “No” button: when “No” is clicked, show an error/try-again message and increase the size (and/or prominence) of the “Yes” button progressively after each “No” click; repeat indefinitely until “Yes” is clicked. Ensure that as the “Yes” button grows, the “No” button becomes effectively hidden behind/under the “Yes” button by the time sufficient “No” clicks occur.

When the user clicks “Yes”, show a popup modal that includes (1) a custom image and (2) the exact note text:
“Yayyy!! You made Jishone the happiest man on earth.
I don’t need big promises. just you, by my side, as we grow and figure life out together”

Establish a cohesive Valentine-themed visual design (colors, typography, spacing, and component styling) and apply it consistently across the homepage, buttons, error message, and modal. Avoid a blue/purple primary palette.
Add the required generated image(s) to the frontend as static assets under `frontend/public/assets/generated/` and reference them directly from the UI (do not serve images from the backend).

Add a couple photo image to the homepage inside the main question card, visually integrated with the existing Valentine theme (rounded corners, subtle border/shadow), and positioned so it does not interfere with the Yes/No interaction (including the Yes button growth behavior).
Add the couple photo as a static asset under `frontend/public/assets/generated/` and reference it directly from the homepage UI (do not serve images from the backend).
Add a user-facing control on the homepage that lets the user choose an image from their device/gallery (via a file picker) and then display the selected image in the homepage couple-photo area.
Validate the selected file as an image and show an English, user-friendly inline message when the file is not a supported image type or cannot be previewed.
Update the homepage question text to use the capitalized name "Annammooo" instead of "annammooo" (keep the rest of the text unchanged).

Add a client-side image upload/picker in the success modal (the second response screen shown after clicking "Yes") that allows the user to select an image from their device and preview it in the modal, similar to the existing homepage image picker behavior.

new_feature_requests.summary: Homepage prompt: “annammooo will you be my valentine” with Yes/No buttons
No-button behavior: show error/try-again message and enlarge Yes button progressively; continue until Yes is selected, with No eventually hidden behind the large Yes button
Yes-button behavior: show popup modal with custom image and the provided celebratory note/message
Add a personal/couple photo image to the website homepage
Allow user to pick an image from their device/gallery and display it on the homepage (client-side upload/preview)
Add an option to choose/upload a custom image on the second response page (client-side picker + preview), similar to the homepage image picker

projectName: Valentine’s interactive Yes/No homepage with escalating Yes button and celebratory modal
